svcproc.title: LATERAL RUNOUT
svcproc.para:
Lateral runout is the movement of the rotor from side to side as it rotates ( Figure 11
). Excessive runout causes the rotor faces to knock back the disc brake pads and can result in chatter, excessive pedal travel, pumping or fighting pedal and vibration during the braking action. This condition can be due to a warped rotor or a loose wheel bearing, especially if symptoms develop immediately after sharp turns, deflection in the steering or the suspension.

Runout is measured by a dial indicator set against the rotor surface approximately 1 inch (25.4 mm) from outer edge of rotor ( Figure 12
). Runout should not exceed .015 inch (.381 mm). Excessive runout will kick back the disc brake pads, cause an increase in pedal travel needed to apply the brakes, and pedal vibration will be felt during applications. It also contributes to "grab," "pull" and noise problems.

Do not overlook wheel bearing adjustment. Wheel bearings which are loose can cause excessive runout indication. For adjusting procedure, refer to GROUP 17-WHEELS, RIMS AND TIRES in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.
If rotor runout exceeds .015 inch (.381 mm), either re-facing or a new rotor assembly will be required.
